And in short, the barriers to recognition can be boiled down to three barriers.
Amongst the global higher education community as a whole, there is still a lack of knowledge about open courseware providers and open courseware courses.
There's a lack of transparency about what's goes behind them.
The institutional procedures, the pedagogy, and the assessment.
And even when we do have quality systems for MC Server open courseware, there's still a lack of trust in the institutional quality procedures that back those up.

To help address this, our solution, first of all, was what Anna was presenting to you as a learning passport and the learning passport, in short, is essentially a descripcion of the learning you've undertaken of the type of institution that is backing up that learning of the quality procedures which were applied to the course, and an explanation of what type of assessment was under gone and how that assessment actually fits in with the institutional.
Or the national ecosystem of assessments.
So a document explaining what this open courseware certificate is is helpful.
But it also has a number of problems.
First of all, you need information from a lot of different factors.
You need information from the course that create from the institution that created the course.
You need information from the student you need information from the institution that's assessing the course.
Because there isn't necessarily the one that produced it.

Secondly, if the recognition instrument is validation of prior learning, validation of prior learning is labor intensive, and if it's labor intensive, it means it's expensive and that introduces a whole set of business model questions which I know have been a hot topic of discussion here.
Thirdly, different institutions use different validation procedures and this makes the harmonization of qualifications even more difficult.
So we were looking at this and saying.
All of this is true, but does it really need to be so difficult?
And what we were thinking of is if you have a mook and there's a thousand students following the smoke.
Let's assume that every one of those students goes back to an institution and asks for recognition of that learning.
Why should 1000 knew recognition processes be started in every one of those institutions?
It's highly inefficient, highly resource, wasteful, and we were trying to figure out if we could find a way to make the learning passport a tool which could be shared.
And so our concept in VM Pass is essentially to crowd source the recognition process between trusted higher education institutions, the networks of trust already exist in Europe.
If you have any CTS, another institution will recognize that the CTS in the US you have a similar system to transferable credits.

So what we said is that we will develop what we call a clearinghouse, an online tool that hosts both the learning passports that are issued together with credits as well as the commentary that is added to those passports by individual institutions.
So I'll walk you through the flow chart here.
